metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Khatau Makanji Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd., Bombay

facts.text: Assessee Company has its year of account ending June 30 every year.
At the close of the account year 1951, assessee carried forward profits amounting to Rs. 30,680 and earned a rebate by declaring dividends below the limit fixed by the Finance Act.

For the account year 1952, book profits were Rs. 28,67,235 less allowances for depreciation and tax; after adjustments, balance available for distribution was Rs. 5,02,915. Income-tax Officer found total income to be Rs. 5,26,681.
For account year 1952, assessee declared dividends amounting to Rs. 4,78,950 and carried forward the balance of Rs. 23,965.
Concerned with assessment year 1953-54; Finance Act, 1953 applicable, applying Finance Act, 1951 with some changes.
Income-tax Officer found assessee had declared excess dividends amounting to Rs. 1,87,691 and calculated additional income-tax at Rs. 21,115-4-0.
Appeals of assessee under Income-tax Act failed.

Appellate Tribunal held excess dividends deemed paid out of undistributed profits of earlier year ending June 30, 1951, amounting to Rs. 6,60,720 on which rebate of 1 anna in the rupee was given in assessment year 1952-53.
Tribunal referred four questions under s. 66(1) of Indian Income-tax Act to Bombay High Court; first question not pressed.
Bombay High Court judgment and order dated August 3, 1956, in Income-tax Reference No. 10 of 1956; answered remaining questions in the negative after modifying them; certified fit for appeal.

legal_issues.text: Whether additional income-tax has been legally charged under clause (ii) of the proviso to paragraph B of Part 1 of the First Schedule to the Indian Finance Act, 1951, as applied to the assessment year 1953-54 by the Indian Finance Act, 1953, read with Section 3 of the Indian Income-tax Act?

petitioner_arguments.text: It was not necessary to look only to s. 3 of the Indian Income-tax Act but also to the provisions of the Finance Act, through which Parliament could impose a new tax.
Suggested modifications of language in Finance Act to sustain the tax independently of s. 3.

respondent_arguments.text: Provisions of Finance Act go beyond ambit of s. 3 of Income-tax Act; additional income-tax not on total income of previous year.

court_reasoning.text: S. 3 of Income-tax Act lays down liability to tax on total income of previous year; Finance Act provides rates but cannot impose tax beyond that without making excess dividends part of total income fictionally.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fiction deems excess dividend out of prior undistributed profits but does not make them total income of previous year under assessment.

court_reasoning.text: Finance Act fails to state that profits of back years shall be deemed part of total income of previous year; tax must be on income of previous year or fictionally so.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Additional income-tax not properly laid on total income as defined in Income-tax Act.

court_reasoning.text: Modifications to language suggested by appellant involve recasting Finance Act, which is for legislature not court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words of Finance Act must be construed as they stand.

court_reasoning.text: Reasons given in Civil Appeal No. 427 of 1957 support view that Finance Act cannot stand independently of s. 3.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Procedure of modifying language not open to court.

holdings.text: High Court was right in answering the question in the negative; additional income-tax not legally charged.

precedents_cited.relevance: Reasons given therein support that Finance Act cannot stand independently of s. 3 of Income-tax Act.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs reference to High Court, liability to tax on total income of previous year, no order under s. 23A, deduction of super-tax.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Finance Act, 1951
sections: Part 1, First Schedule, paragraph B, proviso clause (ii)
statutes_cited.relevance: Provides for rebate and additional income-tax on excess dividends; deems excess out of prior undistributed profits.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Finance Act, 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: Applies Finance Act, 1951 with modifications to assessment year 1953-54.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by the Commissioner, upholding the Bombay High Court's negative answer to the question whether additional income-tax was legally charged under the Finance Act provisions read with s. 3 of the Income-tax Act.
outcome.relief_granted: No additional income-tax payable by assessee.

key_quotes.text: "The Finance Act fails to do is to make them total income, so as to take in the rate which is prescribed for the total income in the Proviso."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning why additional tax provision is ineffective.

key_quotes.text: "Income-tax is a tax on income of the previous year, and it would not cover something which is not the income of the previous year, or made fictionally so."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains limit of legislative fiction in Finance Act.

key_quotes.text: "The ambit of Section 3 is clear and the ambit is that the tax to be levied must be a tax on income and the power of Parliament is equally clear and that is to fix the rate at which income-tax is to be charged upon the total income of the previous year."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes High Court reasoning affirmed by Supreme Court.
